text: I could become passively okay at management with some training, with some coaching. I don't want to spend any years of my life becoming passively okay at something.
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his decision to never have direct reports at HubSpot. Dharmesh explains that during the founding of HubSpot, he realized he wasn't naturally good at management and had failed at it in previous companies. Rather than spending years trying to become mediocre at something he didn't enjoy, he chose to focus his energy on things he was naturally good at and passionate about.
vocabulary_highlights: spend any years of my life
text_ko: 교육이나 코칭을 받으면 그저 그럭저럭 괜찮은 관리자는 될 수 있어요. 그런데 제 인생의 몇 년을 그런 '그저 괜찮은' 상태로 보내고 싶지는 않아요.
text_zh: 通过培训和指导，我可能会成为一个还算过得去的管理者。但我不想把人生中的几年时间花在做一个"还算过得去"的事情上。
text_es: Podría llegar a ser un gerente pasable con algo de capacitación, con un poco de coaching. No quiero desperdiciar años de mi vida volviéndome apenas pasable en algo.

text: It comes down to this metric that stand-up comedians use called LPM laughs per minute. I have custom software that I've written that will say, 'Okay, here are the points at which the audience laugh.'
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks about Dharmesh's unique approach to preparing keynote speeches. Dharmesh explains how he applies engineering principles to public speaking by measuring audience engagement. He records his practice talks, transcribes them, and uses custom software to calculate laughs per minute (LPM) - a metric borrowed from stand-up comedy - to optimize his presentations for maximum audience attention.
text_ko: 결국 스탠드업 코미디언들이 쓰는 LPM(분당 웃음 수, laughs per minute)이라는 지표로 귀결돼요. 제가 직접 만든 맞춤형 소프트웨어가 있어서 관객이 웃는 지점을 정확히 짚어줘요.
text_zh: 说白了就是脱口秀演员用的那个指标，叫每分钟笑点数(LPM - laughs per minute)。我专门写了个软件，能告诉我"好，观众在这些地方笑了"。
text_es: Al final se reduce a esta métrica que usan los comediantes que se llama LPM, risas por minuto (laughs per minute). Tengo un software personalizado que yo mismo desarrollé que me dice: "Mira, estos son los momentos exactos donde se ríe la audiencia."

text: Some of the best startup advice I've heard is startups should focus on one thing and be really, really exceptionally world-class at that one thing. And one of our early zigs is we are going to do exactly the opposite of that.
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his tendency to 'zig when others zag' - making contrarian business decisions. Dharmesh explains one of HubSpot's biggest contrarian bets: instead of focusing on becoming the best at one specific tool, they built an all-in-one platform with multiple products. This went against conventional startup wisdom but solved the real customer problem of SMBs struggling to integrate multiple separate tools.
text_ko: 제가 들은 최고의 스타트업(startups) 조언 중 하나는, 스타트업은 한 가지에 집중해서 그 한 가지에서 정말, 정말 탁월하게 세계 최고가 돼야 한다는 거예요. 그런데 저희가 초반에 한 '지그'(zigs) 중 하나는 바로 그걸 정확히 정반대로 해보겠다는 거예요.
text_zh: 我听过最好的创业建议之一就是，创业公司应该专注做一件事，而且要把这件事做到世界顶级水平。但我们早期的策略恰恰相反，我们要反其道而行之。
text_es: Uno de los mejores consejos para startups que he escuchado es que deberían enfocarse en una sola cosa y ser realmente, pero realmente excepcionales a nivel mundial en esa cosa. Y una de nuestras primeras movidas contrarias es que vamos a hacer exactamente lo opuesto a eso.

text: I think too many founders, once they get to a... They are very apprehensive of going public and going through the IPO process and being a publicly traded company because they think... I mean, that's like the beginning of the end.
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks what lessons Dharmesh has learned from being a public company executive for nearly 10 years. Dharmesh shares his contrarian view that founders are unnecessarily afraid of going public. He argues that while there are additional requirements for public companies, there are significant benefits including real-time market valuation feedback and allowing broader public participation in the company's growth.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 많은 창업자들이 어느 정도 성장하면 상장(going public)이나 IPO 과정(IPO process)을 거쳐 상장사(publicly traded company)이 되는 걸 지나치게 꺼려해요. 그들은 그게 사실상 끝의 시작이라고 생각하거든요.
text_zh: 我觉得太多创始人，一旦他们到了那个阶段...他们对上市特别抵触，不愿意走IPO流程，也不想成为公开交易的公司，因为他们觉得...这就像是走下坡路的开始。
text_es: Creo que muchos fundadores, una vez que llegan a cierto punto... Les da mucho miedo salir a bolsa y pasar por todo el proceso de la OPI (IPO) y convertirse en una empresa que cotiza en bolsa porque piensan... O sea, es como el principio del fin.

text: Culture is a product, period, and that every company builds two products, one is the product they build for their customers, and the other is a product they build for their team. That's what culture is, it's the product you build for your team.
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks Dharmesh about his process for defining and maintaining HubSpot's culture. Dharmesh shares his framework that culture should be treated as a product with employees as customers. This means regularly surveying employees like you would customers, iterating on culture based on feedback, and never considering culture 'finished' - just like you would never stop improving a customer-facing product.
text_ko: 문화는 제품이에요, 그게 핵심이에요. 모든 회사는 사실 두 가지 제품을 만들어요: 하나는 고객을 위한 제품이고, 다른 하나는 팀을 위한 제품이에요. 그 팀을 위한 제품이 바로 문화예요.
text_zh: 企业文化就是一个产品，就这么简单。每个公司其实都在做两个产品，一个是给客户用的产品，另一个是给自己团队用的产品。企业文化就是这样，它就是你为团队打造的那个产品。
text_es: La cultura es un producto, punto. Cada empresa desarrolla dos productos: uno es lo que construyen para sus clientes, y el otro es lo que construyen para su equipo. Eso es la cultura: el producto que desarrollas para tu equipo.

text: Within a closed system, entropy increases over time. We don't have to get into the [inaudible 00:37:50] of this. In lay person's terms, the second law of thermodynamics, I'm paraphrasing here, is that, 'Over time, unless you intervene, everything goes to crap.'
speaker: Dharmesh Shah
context: Lenny asks about Dharmesh's concept that business leaders are fighting the second law of thermodynamics. Dharmesh explains that just like physical systems naturally tend toward disorder without intervention, companies naturally become more complex over time. Leaders must actively fight this entropy by simplifying processes, reducing complexity, and making conscious decisions to maintain organizational efficiency as they scale.
text_ko: 폐쇄계(closed system)에서는 엔트로피(entropy)가 시간이 지날수록 증가해요. 그 부분의 세부사항은 굳이 들어가지 않을게요. 쉬운 말로, 열역학 제2법칙(second law of thermodynamics)을 제가 요약하면 ‘시간이 흐르면 개입하지 않는 한 모든 게 점점 엉망이 돼요’라는 뜻이에요.
text_zh: 在一个封闭系统里，熵会随着时间增加。这个我们就不深入讲了[听不清 00:37:50]。用大白话说，热力学第二定律(second law of thermodynamics)，我这里简单概括一下，就是"时间久了，你要是不管不问，什么东西都会变得一团糟。"
text_es: Dentro de un sistema cerrado, la entropía aumenta con el tiempo. No necesitamos meternos en los detalles técnicos de esto. En términos sencillos, la segunda ley de la termodinámica, parafraseando aquí, es que "con el tiempo, a menos que intervengas, todo se va al carajo."
